The simple fact is major trading currencies do not typically fluctuate in relative value very much over the short term. Volatility between the major currencies tends to be only a few cents or less either way in a normal day and even month. There was a sharp drop in the value of the pound after the Brexit referendum (see link) but since then the pound has stabilized between 1.1 and 1.2; that combined with the fact that starting the Brexit process should be priced in already means there would have to be a truly shocking shock to move the pound outside that band. http://www.exchangerates.org.uk/GBP-EUR-exchange-rate-history.html

Increasing possibility of near-term strengthening of Pound. Seems to be some stabilization between currencies and Brexit question, in near term based on recent parliament votes, have provided support for Brexit (as ambiguous as that may be longer term). There are some uncertainties regarding upcoming French elections which will weigh on the Euro until resolved. DT has professed support to May, so that may add some weight to the scale (if he can ever find his way back to that policy thread given the many other distractions).

The range 1.10 to 1.20 is a very large given the current volatility.  It is very likely to fall inside this range. Surprise negative events are IMHO much more likely from the Eurozone rather than UK, esp relating to political uncertainty, banking or sovereign debt crisis.  These would all be positive for this cross. Fears of Brexit costs to the UK economy are largely overstated and misunderstood, especially relating to trade.  UK trade with the EU will not vanish should even the hardest of Brexits occur.  If the EU was foolish enough to put large tariffs on UK goods then they would be shooting themselves in the foot.  History has shown repeatedly that this form of taxing consumers does not help grow an economy and also tends to have an upward pressure on domestic currency and in doing so make their own exports more difficult (contrary to the intent). On the flip-side, inflation in the EU seems to be picking up.  While this may trigger a sovereign debt crisis (negative for EUR), it may also force the ECB to taper it's QE and possibly leave NIRP (very positive for EUR).  Unlike most central banks, the ECB does not have much discretion when it comes to inflation targeting. It's generally accepted that the BoE made a significant policy error by cutting interest rates and resuming QE immediately after the Brexit vote.  It is quite possible that they will signal intent to hike, or even hike over the next month or two.  Inflation owing to a cheaper GBP may also force their hand.  This hiking would be positive for the GBP.

Deutsche Bank says sterling's reserve status being eroded Sterling's role as a global reserve currency is declining Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday, predicting the pound would be less widely used as Britain leaves the European Union and that China has drastically cut its holdings.Britain needs sterling to hold onto its reserve status because, with one of the biggest current account deficits in the world, it takes hundreds of billions of pounds of capital inflows each year just to balance its books. Central bank demand for sterling reserves has been a critical, stable and reliable source of that funding, and even the slightest decline in holdings of pounds could have a magnified effect on Britain's fiscal well-being.With China now feeding into the International Monetary Fund's closely followed currency reserves data it has become difficult to draw firm conclusions on FX shifts, but Deutsche pointed to other factors suggesting sterling's decline. "We estimate that the pound’s share (of China's reserves) has likely fallen from close to 10 percent into low single digits since early 2015 consistent with the PBoC (People's Bank of China) transitioning from wealth to currency management." 
http://www.reuters.com/article/uk-sterling-reserve-status-deutsche-idUSKBN15925I

It appears that the markets have now factored in the withdrawal of the UK from the single market. Hence, the prediction was updated to 15-65-20, weighted more on loosing more value, because the economists insist that Brexit will spell disaster for the UK, albeit that so far their forecast has not been borne out.

Well, the PM's  speech restored the status quo before the pre-speech panic ensued. As I write, the pound is at 1.1577 against the euro. However, there is a change in sentiment, as the UK government has clearly indicated that non-economic objectives would be prioritized in the Brexit talks with the EU. So the factors positive for the pound (such as the parliamentary discussions, and the likelihood of BoE tightening policy in view of rising inflation) will meet quite a bit of headwind.  Weakness in the euro area is a wild card here - I don't expect much before end-March, but Trump's policies may cause some turbulence. Overall, I raise slightly the probability mass for the 1.1-1.2 range, with a near-symmetric distribution of risks.

Adjustment ahead of Mrs May's speech. Widely trailed as going for a hard Brexit, but in my view this is not really an objective it is more of a negotiating position e.g. "you (the EU) cannot threaten the UK with a bad Brexit deal because we are so keen to leave the EU that a terrible Brexit deal is a price worth paying. The UK is prepared to pay the price of a terrible deal, but is the EU also prepared to pay a price for a bad deal?  Or would it rather offer something better?" 
Its similar to Trump threatening to tax imports from Mexico at 35%. It sounds tough, it shows that the negotiator is prepared to destroy the status quo, but its largely  bluff. To work it depends on getting the other party to believe it is negotiating with an irrational idiot who could do something stupid.
Following the Brexit negotiations, a hard Brexit would deliver a weaker Pound to regaing competitiveness.

I'd like to see the speech before fundamentally revising my forecast, if at all, but current market dynamics substantially reduce the chances of an outcome in the 1.2-1.3 range. The key factors in determining whether the GBP will emerge stronger than the Euro lies in the whether the Bank of England will raise the Bank Rate to fight inflation at the expense of economic growth, and whether Article 50 will be invoked by 31 March 2017. Following 'Brexit', the GBP has taken a pounding (pun intended), as investors opt to flee for safer currency havens (USD, JPY).  Given the current short-termism of investors, I believe 5 factors will come into play in determining the relative exchange rate between the GBP and Euro (at least in the short-term): 1. Timing of the invocation of Article 50 (when it will be announced)
2. Scotland to hold a second referendum to leave the UK to join the Eurozone (Will its happen?)
3. How effective Italy cleans up its ailing banks, especially MPS
4. The trade-offs perceived by the BoE in determining whether to raise rates to fight inflation, or provide monetary easing to support economic growth
5. Whether we have any other countries leaving the Eurozone following the shift to populism.

Mrs May makes speech, is not 100% clear but sounds as if she is more interested in control of immigration than retaining trade links with the EU, pound goes down, businesses lobby for the importance of EU trade to UK. Government clarifies what Mrs May meant, claims that the media misunderstood her words, pound recovers a little. Repeat pattern between now and when A50 is triggered. 
Until Mrs May clarifies the specifics of which categories of immigrants will cease to be admitted to the UK it is a sterile discussion. Mrs May's track record is not very good, as Home Secretary for 6 years in spite of the government having a policy of reducing net immigration to the tens of thousands she made no significant progress in reducing immigration from outside the EU, so why would anyone believe she would reduce immigration from the EU after Brexit? It has already been stated that (a) no one is really concerned with students per se, so they shoud still be welcome (b) well qualified and skilled immigrants will still be welcome (c) farmers, food processors and caterers  have been promised that they will still be able to access a similar number of low skilled, low wage immigrants (d) the problems with the NHS and social care sectors suggest that no one but a fool would not welcome the immigrants that do this work (e) would the UK just block the families of immigrant workers? But actually the goal is answering the wrong question. Research clearly shows that "net migration" is not what voters care about. What the concern over immigration is, is where the percentage annual increase in the number if immigrants in a locality is high. It is the rate of increase not the percentage of immigrants. Voters in place with a high percentage of immigrants did not vote for Brexit, places with a low percentage of immigrants, but where the percentage of immigrants was rising fastest did vote for Brexit. I have no heard of anyone living in a Brexit voting area say that if only more Brits would retire to Spain (and so reduce the net number of immigrants to the UK) they would be happy to have the Brits replaced by Romanians. Net migration figures are totally irreverent.  If you can't describe the problem correctly there is little chance of solving it

PM May announced that article 50 will be triggered no later than 3/31/17. My expectation is that this date will create an extra (near-term) psychological downdraft on the GBP, so my forecasts lean to the downside. At a more macro level, inflation is increasing in Britain faster than its Euro neighbors. Unemployment remains low/stable in comparison. Euro commission retains a loose monetary position that would tend to mitigate a GBP downdraft. Despite a variety of economic "facts" that could show economic equivalence with Euro-states, the psychological overhang could overshadow genral economic landscape.

Most likely outcome 1.15-20. Coming from shortly breaking 1.10 GBP is cleary in an upward moving channel. 1.30 as being a pre-Brexit mark is almost off the table if we don't see any sort tail event. Almost the same holds for again touching 1.10 (slighty higher probability). On the macro side we don't have any major downside risks for GBP. Consumption as biggest contributor to GDP still intact, Investment could be hurt but won't drag down GDP in such a short time frame. EUR economy also seems pretty stable for 2017 start which on the flip side should keep upside in GBP limited. Central Banks also play in the cards for narrow trading as both are most likely on hold for the period. Politically we also face a pretty light agenda with triggering article 50 being the most likely outcome. Even if thats not the case GBP should stay in 1.20-30 area. Nevertheless, If we gonna see a tail Event I expect it to be a political one. Plo

Time to lay down some markers here: Overall, I expect the pound/euro to remain broadly where it is now (i.e., in the 1.10-1.20 range), with mainly upside risks (for the pound): 1. I expect the Supreme Court to rule that triggering Art 50 requires a law. This opens the door for parliamentary scrutiny over the process and reduces the risk of a hard Brexit. Ergo, it's positive for the pound. 2. A delay of the trigger beyond March 31 is a (small) positive for the pound as well, as it gives more time for preparation and reduces the "dead time" between the date of the trigger and the outcome of the French and German elections.  3. Finally, while I don't expect much trouble in the euro area in Q1 (after the Italian decision to create a fund for recapitalizing MPS and possibly other banks), but if trouble does emerge, this should be positive for the pound/euro as well.

Risks all come down to actually leaving the EU, which will make it take a(nother) hit. It's only been below 1.15 briefly in the last five years (right after Brexit vote), but I want to account for Article 50 risks with that 1-1.0 level.

With Italy looking to avoid retail investors suffering bond losses when Monte dei Paschi di Siena is bailed out by claiming they were mis-sold the bonds a new crisis for the Euro appears to be in the offing. Bond holder not tax payers were supposed to take the hit from bailouts in the Euro zone from now on, but if the first test shows that this is not always going to happen, then the credibility of the ECB comes into question. Clearly banks selling bonds in themselves to their own unsophisticated retail customers is a problem. A similar issue occurred during the banking crisis in Spain 5 or 6 years ago, where customers with normal interest bearing deposit accounts at Bankia were persuaded to swap them for higher yields bonds in the bank itself. Many of the customers seems to have thought they were just transferring funds to a different account that would be covered by the EU bank deposit protection scheme (which of course was not the case as they found out when the bank failed). I would have expected that all banks would have been told by their regulators that retail customers needed to warned before they bought Bonds that are not covered by deposit protection. I don't know the situation in Italy but would suspect that there will be a lot of argument between Bond holders, the Italian financial protection authorities, the Italian Government, the ECB , the EU, the EU Parliament and EU countries as to how this question has arisen again only 4 or 5 years after the last time. All this could lower the value of the Euro against the pound. 
With questions about what the future holds for the EU, USA and UK the pound may look a bit less of a risk next year. All concerned will have plenty of opportunity to make any of their currencies look less secure.

It is an interesting closing date. There are two possibilities based on whether the UK government would have invoked Article 50 by that date (and given clues of its negotiating position).  The exchange rate collapsed on Brexit and at the Conservative conference, when May and her inner circle became more open about their intentions, which were perceived as a hard Brexit. In contrast, in Hammond's autumn statement, the pound appreciated slightly. There is also the underlying economics, e.g. growth , deficit, trade balance, as well as politics, which will influence what the Forex traders will do.  The exchange rate is currently at 1.19. The below 1 euro and above 1.3 euro (especially) possibilities can be excluded; as things stand it is not easy to imagine that it will move so far out. Hence the probable range will be between 1.05 euro and 1.25 euro, which spans 3 possible answers. Hence, as a starting point, a proportional probability allocation will be given, assuming a uniform probability distribution over that range. This, of course will have to be updated according to developments.

A lot of uncertainty in UK and EU. For EU important elections will start only later in the year, and more insight in the negotiations with EU and UK will start already in Q1 2017. The latter will be a bit dissappointing for the UK. And although there is quite some interest from foreign companies to pick the cherries in the UK market, i still expect the pound will loose some ground against the Euro, but not too much (current exchange is 1.18 EUR ).
A 7% decline from today seems very plausible.  The extremes are to consider unknowns.

This article suggests 4 other reasons why £ is generally overvalued, in addition to Brexit risks. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-19/deutsche-bank-s-five-reasons-why-the-pound-is-overvalued No doubt by end of March much will depend on developments related to Article 50. Supreme Court ruling in Jan most obvious. Government is also committed to setting out its plan to Parliament before triggering.  Even if SC were to come out strongly against the government in the appeal, or the government's "plan" were to prove controversial or incomplete, it still seems unlikely that the Government will be prevented from triggering Art. 50 by end March, or shortly after, given that Parliament has agreed in principle to sending notification by then. £ currently at 1.19. The main factors affecting the rate are Brexit with various Euro issues (Italian banks, Greece etc.) weighing on the other side. I do not think the final Brexit outcome will be much clearer by the end of March. It is quite likely that A50 will have been delayed (the delay blamed on Parliament not accepting David Davis "Brexit Negocation Position" paper). If a "hard" Brexit looks more likely the pound will fall. If the pound falls too far the government will panic and start talking up a "softer" Brexit. If the pound starts to rise significantly the Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail will will report that Brexit is creating a boom and that the government can safely go for a quicker "harder" Brexit. So I think the "hard" and "soft" Brexit talk will keep the pound about where it is now. Clearly at the moment markets are assuming that some kind of fudge will take place that will allow the UK and EU trade to continue more or less as it does now for an indeterminate period (at least 2 years, maybe 4 years maybe 10 years). So I guess that means they expect industrial investment (in stuff that cannot easily be moved abroad) to continue to decline, while services and investment continues in IP (that can be moved a click of a button). As long as the UK remains open to highly skilled migrants the legacy of the Brexit vote, whatever deal is struck with the EU, will probably to bring forward the UK exit from the manufacturing economy and speed up the move to the IP economy. Probably not what most Brexit people were hoping for.

My previous attempt had math errors, so this is a correction. Assuming the asset value $S_t$ is a Geometric Brownian Motion with $\mu=0$. Thus $S_t$ is a log-normally distributed random variable with expected value $S_0$ and variance given by the formula $(S_t-S_0)^2=S_0^2(\exp(\sigma^2t) -1)$. Solving this variance equation for $\sigma^2$, for each daily $S_t$, where t is the serial day number since 24 June 2016 through 12 December 2016. So this gives a sample of 168 instance values of $\sigma^2$. Taking the average of these values, I come up with the estimate of $\sigma^2$ for the day 31 March 2017 (the new t). This $\sigma$ is not the standard deviation, so I have t use the variance formula above, an estimate of the variance $(S_t-S_0)^2$ for the same day, with $S_0$ at 12 December 2016. Then, using the cumulative distribution function for log-normal distribution with mean $S_0$ and the variance given above, calculated for the bins given in the question, I obtained these results. This calculation can be done in Excel, but the use of the lognormal distribution function in the end is just a little tricky.

What will impact currency is the US Dollar.
For decades, Donald Trump has talked about the importance of a weak dollar and there's no sign of this changing. At the time of writing this (mid December '16) the USD is gaining in strength at the prospect of Trump's pro business presidency. This is irrational exuberance. Everything we know of Trump tells us we'll see a weak dollar and huge amounts of quantitative easing. The question to ask is how will this impact the pound and the euro? It's likely that Sterling (which is already oversold) will strengthen as the impact of Brexit becomes more known and the Euro will weaken as political uncertainty grows with upcoming elections. Therefore a weaker Euro and stronger pound should be expected; but saying that, a reversal in dollar strength will create uncertainty and more volatility than usual.

# A very naive estimate from volatility daily_vola = 0.01
remaining_days = 111
price_today = 1.18662 change = 1.+daily_vola*np.random.randn(remaining_days, 100000)
change_tot = np.product(change,axis=0)
end_price = price_today*change_tot
print sum(end_price<1.)/float(len(end_price))
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.,end_price<1.1))/float(len(end_price))
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.1,end_price<1.2))/float(len(end_price))
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.2,end_price<1.3))/float(len(end_price))
print sum(end_price>1.3)/float(len(end_price))

The pound gained as Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi announced his resignation after suffering a crushing defeat in Sunday’s Italian referendum.  As a result the pound soared against the euro and reached a high of 1.20 – the highest rate in more than six months.   The euro has actually been the strongest performer over the past 24 hours, but the gains are unlikely to halt the pound's recovery.  Today, the pound to euro exchange rate has dropped slightly to 1.17561 (at time of writing) but it's still a huge improvement on the post-Brexit slump. 
The last few months have seen the pound to euro exchange rate soar, after a post-Brexit crash.
